turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, I'm finally ready to tackle painting the living room. I've got the paint, brushes, and tape, but honestly, I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed. Where do I even start?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: No problem! Let's break it down. First, thoroughly clean the walls. Remove any dust, cobwebs, or grease. Next, apply painter's tape along all edges - trim, windows, ceiling. Then, prime the walls if needed, especially if you're painting over a dark color. Does that help?

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Yeah, that makes sense. Clean, tape, prime... got it. But what about the order? Do I tape *before* cleaning? Seems like I'd just be taping over dust.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: You are absolutely right! My apologies. Clean first, *then* tape. Applying tape to a dirty surface won't give you a clean line. Thanks for catching that!

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, good. Now, this primer... the guy at the store said something about different types of primer for different surfaces. How do I know which one to use? My walls are just standard drywall, I think. And, more importantly, does primer color matter? The old paint is a dark red, and I'm going to white.

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: For standard drywall, a good quality multi-purpose latex primer will work perfectly. And yes, the color of the primer *definitely* matters when painting a light color over a dark one. Ask for a tinted primer – have it tinted as close as possible to your final white color. This will significantly reduce the number of coats of white paint you'll need. Otherwise, that red will keep bleeding through!
